docs.text: you would think that this film's dismal failure would be due to american filmmakers getting hold of a brilliant british comedy and " americanizing " it .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: you'd be wrong , since full blame can be placed on the very folks who wrote and created the series : rowan atkinson , robin driscoll , and richard curtis .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: should you ever happen to meet those chaps , do me a favor .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: grab them by the hair and yell really loudly in their ear , " what were you thinking ? !
docs.label: negative

docs.text: have you ever heard the phrase 'if it ain't broke don't fix it' ? ! "
docs.label: negative

docs.text: then walk away .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the film concerns mr . bean ( atkinson ) and his visit to america while escorting the painting of " whistler's mother " to an american buyer ( played by burt reynolds , in the type of bit part that his success in " boogie nights " should hopefully do away with ) .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: now how or why mr . bean is sent on this trip makes no sense , and i can't even describe how the film explains it .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the point is that mr . bean comes to america and causes wacky trouble .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: problems problems problems , where to begin ?
docs.label: negative

docs.text: first , the score music from the tv show has been completely replaced by score that is either at times one note away from the score from " beetlejuice " or one note away from the score from " rob roy " .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: then , the song choices are totally uninspired .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: " good vibrations " ?
docs.label: negative

docs.text: " i love l . a . " ?
docs.label: negative

docs.text: wow , don't put any thought into that guys .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: also , bean makes way too much noise in the film .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the character doesn't speak much , but in the series you really only heard the laughter of the audience , and maybe the occasional murmur from mr . bean .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: each episode was like a chaplin silent movie .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: in the film , bean is constantly moaning , grunting , whining , etc . it's annoying , and just plain wrong for the character .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the main problem though is that it's just not funny .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: with each episode of the series there would be dozens of really great laughs crammed into less than 30 minutes .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: multiply that running time by three however , and the laughs steadily decrease .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: they even have the gaul to repeat jokes from the series .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: sad , and creatively lazy .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: as a series , " mr . bean " only ran for about 13 episodes or so .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: why on earth did atkinson and the gang decide it was time to completely rework everything ?
docs.label: negative

docs.text: 13 half-hour episodes certainly hadn't exhausted all possible situations .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: all i can say positively for the film at this point is that it's almost appropriate for all ages , if it wasn't for a couple of scenes where it appears as though mr . bean is having sex with things .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: and even that isn't a very positive statement .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: please guys , go back to england and go back to television so you'll make me laugh again .
docs.label: negative
